chapters.title: Comments
chapters.description: Comments can be used to explain javascript code. comments will be ignored by the interpreter

examples.title: Single-Line Comments
examples.code: // This is a single line comments
examples.description: Single line comments can be written at the end of line of a code.

examples.title: Multi-Line Comments
examples.description:
• Multi-line comments used to write documentation.
• /* is the start of the comment and */ is the end of the comment

chapters.title: Variables
chapters.description: Variables are containers for storing data.

examples.title: Using var
examples.description: The var keyword should only be used in code written for older browsers. var keyword allows us to redelare the same variable and it will let the variable access out of the scope.

examples.title: Using Let
examples.description: Let keyword is modern replacement for var. It fixes the problems with var.

examples.title: Using Const
examples.description: Const keyword is used to define a constant value that should not be allowed to change.

chapters.title: Identifiers
chapters.description: JavaScript identifiers are names used to identify variables, functions, objects, or any other constructs within a JavaScript program.

examples.title: Rules for Identifiers
examples.description:
1. Identifiers must begin with a letter (a-z, A-Z), an underscore (_), or a dollar sign ($).
2. After the first character, identifiers can also contain digits (0-9).
3. Identifiers are case-sensitive, meaning 'myVariable' and 'myvariable' are considered different.

examples.title: Valid Examples
examples.code:
let myVariable
let _privateVar
let $specialVar
let firstName
let calculateSum

examples.title: Invalid Examples
examples.code:
let 123var // starts with a digits
let my-variable // contains a hyphen
let my variable // contains a space

examples.title: Keywords
examples.description:
• We can't use javascript reversed words.
• The reversed words are called keyword.
• Example: `if`, `else`, `for`, `while`, and many more
examples.code:
let for // invalid 
let function // invalid

chapters.title: Naming Conventions
chapters.description:
• Naming conventions are set of rules and guildelines used in programmming to define how identifiers should be named.
• They are used to make the code more readable.
• They are used to seperate words and use of specific prefixes or suffixes.

examples.title: Camel Case
examples.description: It's a common convention to use camel case for variable and function names in JavaScript. In camel case, the first word starts with a lowercase letter, and subsequent words are capitalized
